title: Basic VAR Modeling
text: VAR models provide a flexible framework for capturing dynamic relationships between macroeconomic variables. By modeling each variable as a function of its own past and the past of others, we can simulate impulse responses and forecast interdependencies. Identification, however, remains the key challenge.

title: Growth Theory
text: Economic growth theory has evolved from the neoclassical Solow model to more nuanced approaches that incorporate human capital, technology, and institutions. While measurement challenges persist (especially for TFP) growth accounting remains a useful tool for cross-country comparisons.

title: Factorial Analysis Methods
text: Factorial analysis methods offer a window into complex data by reducing dimensionality while preserving structure. Techniques like Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Correspondence Analysis (CA) help uncover latent patterns, often invisible in raw data, and are especially useful in the social sciences, where interpretability matters.

title: About this Blog
text:
This blog is an experiment in quiet knowledge building.
Most entries are drawn from my current projects in macroeconomics, econometrics, and teaching ‚Äî particularly on topics like structural models, Bayesian inference, dimensionality reduction, and growth theory.
It‚Äôs a personal project, but one I hope will resonate with others navigating similar intellectual paths.

title: Bayesian Models
text: Bayesian methods offer a coherent way to incorporate prior knowledge and uncertainty into economic models. From shrinkage priors in VARs to hierarchical structures, Bayesian techniques can stabilize inference and handle limited data scenarios ‚Äî common in macroeconomic applications.

title: Business Cycle Filters
text: Business cycle filters are tools that separate long-term trends from short-term fluctuations in macroeconomic data. While they are not grounded in structural theory, filters like HP, Baxter-King, or Hamilton are often used for descriptive analysis. Each has strengths, weaknesses, and assumptions worth making explicit.

title: Max-Share Identification: A Step-by-Step Example in R
text:
Introduction
In VAR analysis, max-share identification aims to extract a structural shock that explains the largest share of the forecast error variance (FEV) of a target variable over a finite horizon.
This post walks through a simple example using two variables: TFP and Stock, from a dataset you can download below.
üìÑ Download the data



Step 1: Load the Data

df <- read.csv("media/datamaxide.csv")
head(df)

  Time        TFP       Stock
1    0  0.0000000  0.00000000
2    1 -1.3224297  0.20060020
3    2 -0.7380925  0.24619445
4    3 -2.3418298 -0.78696549
5    4 -1.7381671  0.04828437
6    5 -0.7563373  0.20709412




Step 2: Estimate a VAR model

library(vars)

data_var <- df[, c("TFP", "Stock")]
colnames(data_var) <- c("y1", "y2")  # rename for generality
var_model <- VAR(data_var, p = 1, type = "const")
summary(var_model)


VAR Estimation Results:
========================= 
Endogenous variables: y1, y2 
Deterministic variables: const 
Sample size: 99 
Log Likelihood: -247.351 
Roots of the characteristic polynomial:
0.7424 0.6237
Call:
VAR(y = data_var, p = 1, type = "const")


Estimation results for equation y1: 
=================================== 
y1 = y1.l1 + y2.l1 + const 

      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
y1.l1  0.73314    0.07228  10.143   <2e-16 ***
y2.l1 -0.01460    0.08773  -0.166    0.868    
const  0.12129    0.10613   1.143    0.256    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1


Residual standard error: 0.9155 on 96 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-Squared: 0.5312, Adjusted R-squared: 0.5214 
F-statistic: 54.39 on 2 and 96 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 


Estimation results for equation y2: 
=================================== 
y2 = y1.l1 + y2.l1 + const 

      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
y1.l1 -0.06913    0.06815  -1.014   0.3129    
y2.l1  0.63297    0.08272   7.652 1.54e-11 ***
const  0.24946    0.10007   2.493   0.0144 *  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1


Residual standard error: 0.8631 on 96 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-Squared: 0.3822, Adjusted R-squared: 0.3693

Covariance matrix of residuals:
       y1     y2
y1 0.8381 0.2914
y2 0.2914 0.7450

Correlation matrix of residuals:
       y1     y2
y1 1.0000 0.3688
y2 0.3688 1.0000




Step 3: Compute the Cholesky-Based IRFs

irf_chol <- irf(var_model, impulse = "y1", response = "y2", n.ahead = 10, ortho = TRUE)
plot(irf_chol)










Step 4:Apply Max-Share Identification

library(expm)

# Step 1: Get A0 matrix (Cholesky)
Sigma_u <- summary(var_model)$covres
A0 <- t(chol(Sigma_u))

# Step 2: Define shock candidates
gamma1 <- c(0, 1)
gamma2 <- c(1, 0)

# Step 3: Structural shocks on impact
A0 %*% gamma1

        [,1]
y1 0.0000000
y2 0.8022985

A0 %*% gamma2

        [,1]
y1 0.9154508
y2 0.3183320




Step 5: Interpretation of results
By testing various candidate shocks (unit vectors or linear combinations), we find the shock that explains the most of TFP‚Äôs variance. This approach generalizes Cholesky ‚Äî we‚Äôre not just assuming an ordering, but optimizing based on information from the FEV


Conclusion
This simple example illustrates the core logic of max-share identification: Find the linear combination of reduced-form errors that best explains your target variable over time.
Future posts will automate the search over vectors and show applications in larger systems.


References
Francis, Ramey, and others (2007). ‚ÄúA New Measure of Monetary Shocks: Derivation and Implications.‚Äù
Boer, Lee & Sun (2024). IMF Working Paper.

title: Papers
text: This page presents my academic publications and current research projects in macroeconomics. My work focuses on external imbalances, fiscal policy, structural heterogeneity, and the dynamics of global economic shocks.

title: Papers
text:
Publications

üìÑ Spatial Dependence, Social Networks, and Economic Structures in Japanese Regional Labor Migration
Sustainability, 2022, 14(3), 1865.
This paper examines how spatial dependence, social networks, and economic structures shape internal labor migration patterns in Japan. Using spatial econometric models, it highlights the complex interplay between regional labor flows and structural characteristics.


üìÑ Is Inflation Fiscally Determined?
Sustainability, 2021, 13(20), 11306.
This paper investigates the relationship between fiscal policy and inflation for 44 countries from 1960 to 2020. Using panel data analysis, it explores whether inflation dynamics can be explained by fiscal dominance, providing evidence across advanced and developing economies.

title: Papers
text:
Working Papers

üìù Global Shocks, Local Structures: Mapping the Anatomy of External Adjustment
This paper examines how structural differences in countries‚Äô external sector configurations shape their macroeconomic responses to global shocks. Using principal component analysis (PCA) on detailed balance-of-payments and trade specialization data for over 150 countries, it constructs a low-dimensional typology of external structures‚Äîcapturing reliance on external income flows, foreign direct investment, trade composition, and vulnerability to essential import needs. The paper then estimates local projections of the current account response to three standardized global shocks: geopolitical risk, world industrial production, and commodity prices. Results reveal sharp asymmetries: geopolitical and output shocks disproportionately affect countries reliant on FDI or remittance flows, while commodity shocks generate textbook terms-of-trade effects, benefiting exporters and penalizing structurally vulnerable importers. The findings highlight the importance of structural heterogeneity in external adjustment and call for more tailored approaches to external risk assessment and macroeconomic policy design.


üìù Cyclical Reaction of Fiscal Policy and its Relationship with the Current Account Balance
This paper examines the link between fiscal policy cyclicality and current account (CA) balances across 51 countries using a structural panel vector autoregression model. It shows that negative CA responses to government spending shocks are primarily observed in countercyclical economies, with substantial heterogeneity across countries. The analysis reveals that subsidies play a significant role in CA adjustments for some countries (e.g., Austria, Croatia, Spain, Bolivia), while property income is a major determinant in countries with high debt and sovereign risk. In contrast, other fiscal components like compensation of employees, intermediate consumption, and social benefits play a minor role.


üìù Effects of Fiscal Stimulus Policies on Private Consumption: A RS-DSGE Approach for Japan
This paper uses a New-Keynesian model with non-Ricardian households to analyze the impact of different fiscal policy measures on private consumption in Japan. The model is solved and estimated outside and at the Zero Lower Bound (ZLB) through a Markov-switching approach, using Japanese data over the period 1980Q1‚Äì2020Q3, and following two different fiscal rule specifications. Results show that consumption does not respond positively to fiscal stimulus measures, even after including rule-of-thumb consumers. This reflects Ricardian behavior and the decline in real wages that follows most measures. Tax distortions influence the variables‚Äô responses through the impact of tax rate movements. The presence of the ZLB does not significantly alter the model‚Äôs behavior except after a consumption or wage income tax cut. A capital income tax cut is found to be the most effective fiscal stimulus measure, primarily boosting investment and productivity. A variance decomposition analysis reveals that consumption is mainly driven by labor supply and technology shocks.
